On 25 May 2010 08:46, Ken <kstanley@...> wrote:
> I see where you're coming from. The multiplication examples are indeed interesting. Have you
> tried running the inputs to neurons (after they run over their incoming connections) through
> logarithms? I wonder what networks would do with logs at all their inputs. Maybe the nodes
> would then only need to be linear summations (because logs provide nonlinearities). Or maybe
> they could still run their usual activation function set.

I think if we acknoweldge the possibility that there is some (possibly
significant) functionality in dendritic trees then the traditional ANN
model isn't as 'broken' as that might suggest - so long as we accept
that single ANN nodes aren't a simplification of single neurons but
rather a representation of a fundamental unit of processing. That is,
we let go of the one-to-one mapping of neuron==ANN node.  From there
we could e.g. add a log(x) activation function to our set of CPPN
activation functions (as a first experiment).

> In general, there is definitely room for the neural model to be improved. The main impediment
> to progress in this area is probably just that it is not very glorious work to be fiddling with
> different function sets and network models and hoping to see a breakthrough, but it is true
> there could be a payoff.

Sure. The fact that Christof Koch wrote a whole book subtitled
"Information processing in single neurons" suggests there might be
more to neurons than a simple sigmoid input-response behaviour :)


> But I'm not saying there isn't something better. I'm just saying it's hard to tell if there is a problem or
> not that needs fixing. There may be and I would be very interested if something superior was
> demonstrated. Will the new SharpNEAT provide an ability to play with such ideas?

Yes it's certainly more geared up for experimenting with different
types of genome without having to hack about in the core code at all.
In short I've used generics (similar concept to C++ templates) to
abstract away the core algorithms (evolution, speciation) from the
genome implementation. So the idea is you devise whatever genome you
want along with the 'phenome' implementation and then plug in some
code that 'decodes' the genome to the phenome
(IGenomeDecoder<TGenome,TPhenome> interface). The speciation
abstraction works by defining the genomes position in an N dimensional
space - that is, you have to translate the 'guts' of the genome into a
N-dimensional position and teh speciation works on those positions -
it's completely abstracted away from the genome classes.

I'll respond to one of your other points in a further post.

Colin
